Award.AwardTitle: Systematics of Magnaporthaceae: Understanding Evolution of the Rice Blast Fungus and Allied Species Using Phylogenetic, Phylogenomic and Comparative Genome Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The family Magnaporthaceae contains devastating fungal pathogens of cereals and grasses, such as the rice blast fungus and summer patch pathogen of turfgrasses, which are popular model systems in studies that seek to understand pathogenesis and fungal biology. Despite their ecological and economic importance, the relationships of Magnaporthaceae to other fungal families and of the constituent genera to one another remain ambiguous. This hinders advancement toward the understanding of pathogenesis and ecological success. New DNA sequence data will be generated for representative species using next-generation sequencing methods. The objectives of the study are to: 1) circumscribe the Magnaporthaceae and to resolve relationships of and within the family using phylogenetic and phylogenomic analyses; 2) generate draft genome assemblies of selected species in the Magnaporthaceae; 3) discover and describe new species in the Magnaporthaceae.

Magnaporthaceae serves as a model system for understanding interactions between fungal pathogenic organisms and their host plants. The novel data will augment a rapidly growing number of fungal genomes generated by NSF-funded "tree of life" projects and other national and international initiatives. They will lead to a better understanding of the evolution of genomes and gene families and of how this evolution leads to the ability of fungi to become pathogenic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The family Magnaporthaceae contains devastating fungal pathogens of cereals and grasses, such as the rice blast fungus and summer patch pathogen of turf grasses. The rice blast fungus is the most destructive disease of rice, which is a staple food source for about half of the world's human population. This fungus also is a popular model system in studies that seek to understand plant-fungal interactions and pathogenesis. Despite their scientific and economic importance, fungi in this family have not been studied comprehensively, and the diversity, taxonomy and evolutionary relationships of these species remain unsettled. This hinders advancement toward the understanding of pathogenesis and ecological success.

 

The objectives of this project were to study the evolution of the rice blast and allied fungi, to generate genome data of selected species, and to discover and describe novel fungi. Using next-generation sequencing methods, genome sequencing for 5 species and transcriptome sequencing for 23 species have been completed. The PIs have reconstructed the evolutionary tree based on these new genome data, which provided solid basis for better understanding of the evolution of these species.  Taxonomic revisions also have been done based on the robust evolutionary tree.  Field trips have been conducted in the New Jersey Pine Barrens, USA, and Yunnan tropical forests, China, which yielded over 1,500 fungal isolates in about 300 species, among which over 100 are undescribed. The field studies thus revealed a new fungal diversity hotspot-- the pine barrens. Three new genera and eleven new species have been published based on the pine barrens collections. Description of additional novel fungal taxa is in progress. Plant growth promotion function was discovered from some of the novel fungi that are dominant root associates in the pine barrens plants.

 

The grant has supported 14 peer-reviewed papers, two other journal publications and two book chapters, with more forthcoming. PI Zhang also developed a website http://magnaporthe.blogspot.com for researchers and user community to discuss and vote on the scientific name for the rice blast fungus, which has had over 24,100 pageviews from 25 countries. Genome data have been deposited in GenBank and posted on the lab webpage (http://dblab.rutgers.edu/FunGI/). Two postdoctoral fellows had been trained in this project. The project also provided support and/or research opportunities for a PhD student, six undergraduate students and two high school students. PI Ning Zhang and Co-PI Debashish Bhattacharya organized an international workshop on “Comparative genomic approaches to understanding the evolution of Magnaporthales” at Rutgers University in January 2016, which is an important Broader Impacts component of this project. The Magnaporthales genome workshop also has disseminated results and data to the communities of interest.
